title: Deploy an Oracle database for OO Workflow Designer
content:
To deploy OO Workflow Designer using Oracle, you must have an existing Oracle database service. If you need to create a new database instance/service, see the relevant documentation provided by Oracle, because this information isn't included within this guide. However, this section contains recommendations for the Oracle instance configuration.

Workflow for Oracle deployment

To deploy OO Workflow Designer using Oracle, perform the following steps:

  1. Review sizing guidelines.
  2. Review software requirements for Oracle SQL database
  3. Configure an Oracle Database.
  4. Manually Create an OO Workflow Designer Database on an Oracle instance
  5. (Optional) Connect OO Workflow Designer to an Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC) environment. This step is only relevant if you are using OO Workflow Designer in an Oracle RAC environment.

Review sizing guidelines

For information to review sizing guidelines, see Set up database environment for OO Workflow Designer topic.

Review system requirements for Oracle SQL database

For information to review software and hardware requirements for Oracle SQL Server database, see System requirements topic.

See the Oracle documentation for supported platforms.

The Oracle 12c RAC environment is supported in backward compatible form. New features such as multiple cluster subnets for SCAN listener aren't supported.

Oracle connector

The JDBC connector jar fie isn't provided with the OO Workflow Designer installation. You must download it and place it under each OO Workflow Designer <installation folder>/designer/lib folder. Verify that the connector version you are using is fully compatible with your database server version. The recommended driver is the Oracle JDBC driver version Oracle 19.3.0.0 ojdbc 8

Language support

You should set the Oracle instance character set to AL32UTF8. This enables using any Unicode character (and practically all common characters in all languages).

Configure an Oracle database

This topic contains information on the Oracle instance and database configuration settings. You can install an OO Workflow Designer database in an Oracle clustered environment (Oracle RAC or other). Legend:

  • Mandatory configuration options/values appear in bold text.
  • Recommended configuration options/values appear in bold Italic text.
  • Supported configuration options/values appear in normal font, and may show as a comma separated list.
Oracle Database
Instance/Server Options
Instance configuration options Defaults, unless instructed otherwise
Mandatory Recommended Supported
PROCESSES >= 500
SESSIONS >= 555
TIMED_STATISTICS TRUE TRUE, FALSE
OPEN_CURSORS >= 900
Shared/Dedicated Server Dedicated Dedicated, Shared
UNDO_ MANAGEMENT AUTO Automatic, Manual
Undo size >= 4GB 6GB – 10GB
Memory Management ASMM AMM, ASMM
MEMORY_TARGET 0 (disabled) >= 5G (for AMM)
SGA_TARGET 8G – 12G >= 4G (for ASMM)
SGA_MAX_SIZE 8G – 12G >= 4G (for ASMM)
PGA_AGGREGATE_TARGET 1G – 2G >= 500M (for ASMM)

All values reflect resources required by OO Workflow Designer. If OO Workflow Designer shares the Oracle instance with other users, these values should be added to whatever is currently consumed by others.

Oracle SQL Database
Instance/Server Options
Mandatory Recommended Supported
File system ASM, Any
Storage options Locally managed tablespace
Automatic segment space management (ASSM)
Automatic local extent management
ARCHIVELOG mode ARCHIVELOG ARCHIVELOG, NOARCHIVELOG
Redo Log total size >= 600MB 1GB

Note that all values reflect resources required by OO Workflow Designer. If OO Workflow Designer shares the Oracle instance with other users, these values should be added to whatever is currently consumed by others.

Manually Create an OO Workflow Designer Database on an Oracle instance

The OO Workflow Designer installation wizard gives the following options during installation:

  • Create a new OO Workflow Designer database, user, and password on your chosen database server or instance.
  • Connect to an existing OO Workflow Designer database on your chosen database server or instance.

Create OO Workflow Designer database using OO Workflow Designer installation wizard

Role Location Privileges required
System administrator, Database administrator, or any user Database server using the installation wizard Data Definition Language (DDL) and Data Manipulation Language (DML)

To create an OO Workflow Designer database:

  1. In the Database configuration screen of the installation wizard, select Create the database/schema option.
  2. Enter the user credentials having CREATE database privileges. For example, SYSTEM
  3. Create a new OO Workflow Designer database and database user.

At this point, only the database, login, and user are created. Objects such as tables and indexes get created when OO starts for the first time after installation.

To connect to an existing OO Workflow Designer database:

  1. Make sure the database name and user are already created on the desired database server or instance.
  2. In the Database configuration screen of the installation wizard, select Connect to an existing database/schema option.
  3. Enter the existing database name and user credentials to establish a connection. For example, oodesignerdb and oodesignerdbuser.

Create OO Workflow Designer database using the Oracle SQL database server or instance

Role Location Privileges required
Database administrator or any user Database server using the installation wizard DDL and DML

If you're an authorized user with elevated privileges to create a new OO Workflow Designer database but don't wish to create an OO Workflow Designer database using the installation wizard. Then you may request your organization's database administrator to create an OO Workflow Designer database and the user name of your choice. After the database administrator creates the OO Workflow Designer database and user for you with the required permission, you can then connect to an existing database using basic privileges.

Review the following general notes for a database administrator:

  • Any user with database administrator role has enough privileges (CREATE USER) to create a new user.
  • Perform the following procedures only if you are an experienced Oracle database administrator.
  • If you prefer to use the database creation wizard/GUI, make sure you select all options that correspond with the SQL code presented below.
  • Not all database creation options are specified—only those that differ from the default value. When in doubt, use default values.

To create a database on the Oracle SQL server:

  1. You can use the create database scripts from:
    1. The downloaded and extracted installation zip at:  <oo_version>\config\sql\Designer\Oracle
    2. The downloaded and extracted database scripts from ITOM Marketplace at: OO_Database_Creation\Designer\Oracle\
  2. Log in to Oracle SQL Server using a role that has CREATE DATABASE permission.
  3. Navigate to the create database script from the extracted zip packages at: <oo_version>\config\sql\Designer\Oracle\ or OO_Database_Creation\Designer\Oracle\
  4. Edit and run the create database script oracle_create_wd_db.sql, and then verify that the database, login, and user were created successfully. You may have to adapt the script parameters to match your environment. 
  5. (Optional) To verify that the database objects can be created by the new login and user:
    1. Connect to the Oracle SQL database server.
    2. Log in using the OO Workflow Designer ’s newly created login role credentials.
    3. Navigate to the test database script from the extracted zip packages at: <oo_version>\config\sql\Designer\Oracle\ or OO_Database_Creation\Designer\Oracle\
    4. Run the database test script oracle_create_test_table.sql, and then verify that the script ran correctly without any errors or warnings.

Connect to Oracle using SID or service name

Connecting to an Oracle database server requires you to specify either the SID (system ID) or Service Name. OO Workflow Designer supports specifying the service name during installation (using either the Installation Wizard or a silent installation). The following examples show how to format JDBC URL of each option, as it should appear in the database.properties file under the designer\conf folder. Connecting to an Oracle instance using the SID:

jdbc.url=jdbc\:oracle\:thin\:@DB_HOSTNAME_OR_IP\:PORT\:SID

Connecting to an Oracle instance using the Service Name:

jdbc.url=jdbc\:oracle\:thin\:@//DB_HOSTNAME_OR_IP\:PORT/SERVICE_NAME

Additional guidelines for Oracle

This topic contains the configuration that needs to be done for OO Workflow Designer to work with Oracle 12cR1 Real Application Cluster (RAC) environments. This information is for advanced users only.

Oracle RAC

A cluster is a collection of interconnected servers that appear as one server to the end user and to applications. Oracle Real Application Cluster (RAC) is Oracle's solution for high availability, scalability, and fault tolerance. It's based on clustered servers that share the same storage. Oracle RAC is a single Oracle database installed on a cluster of hardware servers. Each server runs an instance of the database and all the instances share the same database files. For more details about Oracle RAC, see the Oracle Clusterware Guide and the Oracle Real Application Clusters Administration and Deployment Guide in the Oracle documentation set of your release. In this topic, the following Oracle RAC example is used:

  • Oracle RAC Cluster name: OORAC
  • Service Name: ORCL.MY.DOMAIN
  • Machine names: Server1, Server2
  • On each machine, there is an Oracle instance of OORAC:
    • SID on Server1: OORAC1
    • SID on Server2: OORAC2
  • On each machine, there is a virtual IP (Server1-Vip and Server2-Vip):
    • Server1-Vip is assigned to Server1
    • Server2-Vip is assigned to Server2 The virtual IP is in addition to the static IP assigned to the machine.
  • SCAN listener uses a virtual IP, usually published using DNS/GNS: SCAN-Vip
  • The local listeners on both servers listen on the default port 1521 and support the database service OORAC. SCAN listener(s) reside on one of the cluster nodes, and may failover along with their virtual IP addresses in the case of a failure. Although 12c SCAN allows configuring multiple SCAN listeners (per subnet), OO Workflow Designer only supports connecting to a single 12c SCAN listener.

Single client access name

Oracle introduced the Single Client Access Name (SCAN), as a preferred access method for clients connecting to the RAC. In this method, clients aren't required to configure individual nodes in the RAC. They rather use a single virtual IP known as the SCAN or the SCAN VIP. The SCAN is a single network name defined for the cluster either in your organization's Domain Name Server (DNS) or in the Grid Naming Service (GNS) that rotates between several IP addresses, reflecting multiple listeners in the cluster. The SCAN eliminates the need to change clients when nodes are added to or removed from the cluster. The SCAN and its associated IP addresses provide a stable name for clients to use for connections, independent of the nodes that make up the cluster. 12c SCAN allows configuring multiple SCAN listeners–one per subnet. OO Workflow Designer only supports connecting to a single 12c SCAN listener. 

Configure OO Workflow Designer to work with Oracle RAC

Connecting to a SCAN Listener Virtual IP

  1. In the OO Designer installation wizard Database Connection page, enter the SCAN listener virtual IP address/network name in the Hostname or IP address field.
  2. Select the Service Name radio button instead of the SID radio button and enter the Oracle RAC service name.
  3. Enter the rest of the details and click the Test Connection button.

Providing the SCAN listener virtual IP address guarantees that the OO Workflow Designer server will be able to reconnect to the database in the case of a failure. This connection method is the preferred one as it enables the OO Workflow Designer installation wizard to create the database and populate it. For silent installation use (replace the highlighted text with the actual values):

db.url=jdbc:oracle:thin:@//[SCAN-Vip]:[PORT]/[ORCL.MY.DOMAIN]

Load Balancing using an explicit connection string

Although using Oracle’s SCAN listener virtual IP is the preferred method, you can also offer an explicit connection string by using the Other database installation option.

Following is an example of how a load balancing connection string would appear in the OO Workflow Designer database.properties file.

  1. Back up your current database.properties file located under < installation>/designer/conf if you have an existing (usable) database connection.
  2. Edit the database.properties file as follows while replacing the highlighted items with the values that match your environment. When copying scripts, note that you may need to remove redundant line breaks from the copied version.
jdbc.url=jdbc\:oracle\:thin\:@
(DESCRIPTION=(LOAD_BALANCE=on)(ADDRESS_LIST=
(ADDRESS=(PROTOCOL=TCP)(HOST=Server1-Vip)(PORT=1521))
(ADDRESS=(PROTOCOL=TCP)(HOST=Server2-Vip)(PORT=1521)))
(CONNECT_DATA=(SERVICE_NAME=ORCL.MY.DOMAIN)))

You must note that the jdbc.url above is broken into several lines for readability, while it should appear as a single line in the actual configuration file. When Load Balancing is set to “on”, failover between listeners is active by default.
